unnormalised: Infectious diseases remain a significant public health concern in India, contributing substantially to morbidity and mortality rates across all age groups. The burden of these diseases is exacerbated by factors such as population density, inadequate sanitation, limited access to healthcare, and varying levels of awareness regarding preventive measures. This article aims to provide an overview of the prevalence, challenges, and management strategies for infectious diseases in the Indian context.

unnormalised: Several infectious diseases are endemic to India, including tuberculosis (TB), malaria, dengue fever, and enteric fever (typhoid). TB continues to be a major public health challenge, with India accounting for a significant proportion of the global TB burden. The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP), now known as the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), has been instrumental in reducing TB incidence and mortality rates. However, challenges persist in the form of drug-resistant TB strains, such as MDR-TB and XDR-TB, which require more complex and expensive treatment regimens. As of 2023, India had an estimated 2.6 million TB cases, highlighting the need for intensified efforts to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) target of eliminating TB by 2025.
normalised: Several infectious diseases are endemic to India, including tuberculosis (T-B), malaria, dengue fever, and enteric fever (typhoid). T-B continues to be a major public health challenge, with India accounting for a significant proportion of the global T-B burden. The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (R-N-T-C-P), now known as the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (N-T-E-P), has been instrumental in reducing T-B incidence and mortality rates. However, challenges persist in the form of drug-resistant T-B strains, such as M-D-R-T-B and X-D-R-T-B, which require more complex and expensive treatment regimens. As of two thousand and twenty three, India had an estimated two point six million T-B cases, highlighting the need for intensified efforts to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal (S-D-G) target of eliminating T-B by two thousand and twenty five.

unnormalised: Vector-borne diseases like malaria and dengue fever also pose a substantial threat to public health. Malaria, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, is prevalent in several states, particularly in rural and tribal areas. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) implements various strategies for malaria control, including insecticide spraying, distribution of insecticide-treated bed nets (ITNs), and early diagnosis and treatment. Dengue fever, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, has witnessed a surge in cases in recent years, particularly in urban and peri-urban areas. The symptoms of dengue range from mild fever and body aches to severe complications such as dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS). Effective vector control measures, community awareness campaigns, and timely clinical management are crucial for mitigating the impact of dengue outbreaks. The reported dengue cases in Delhi NCR alone touched 1500 between Jan and Oct '23.

Effective vector control measures, community awareness campaigns, and timely clinical management are crucial for mitigating the impact of dengue outbreaks. The reported dengue cases in Delhi N-C-R alone touched one thousand and five hundred between January and October two thousand and twenty three.

unnormalised: Enteric fever, primarily caused by Salmonella Typhi and Salmonella Paratyphi, remains a common waterborne disease in India. Poor sanitation, contaminated water sources, and inadequate hygiene practices contribute to the transmission of these pathogens. Vaccination against typhoid fever is recommended for individuals residing in or traveling to endemic areas. Other infectious diseases of concern include viral hepatitis (A, B, C, and E), HIV/AIDS, and various respiratory infections. Hepatitis B and C are major causes of chronic liver disease and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in India. The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) implements comprehensive HIV prevention and control programs, focusing on awareness generation, condom promotion, and antiretroviral therapy (ART).

The National A-I-D-S Control Organisation (N-A-C-O) implements comprehensive H-I-V prevention and control programs, focusing on awareness generation, condom promotion, and antiretroviral therapy (A-R-T).

unnormalised: Addressing the challenges posed by infectious diseases requires a multi-pronged approach, encompassing improved sanitation, access to safe drinking water, enhanced healthcare infrastructure, and effective disease surveillance systems. The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, a nationwide cleanliness campaign, aims to improve sanitation and hygiene practices, which are essential for preventing waterborne and foodborne infections. Strengthening primary healthcare services, particularly in rural areas, is crucial for early diagnosis and treatment of infectious diseases. The National Health Mission (NHM) plays a vital role in improving healthcare access and reducing out-of-pocket expenditure for healthcare services.

unnormalised: Public awareness campaigns are essential for promoting preventive behaviors, such as handwashing, safe food handling, and mosquito bite prevention. Collaboration between government agencies, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and community stakeholders is crucial for implementing effective disease control programs. Furthermore, research and development efforts are needed to develop new diagnostics, vaccines, and therapeutic agents for infectious diseases. As of March 10, '24, trials are ongoing for a new vaccine against Chikungunya at AIIMS, New Delhi. The integration of traditional medicine systems, such as Ayurveda and Unani, into the healthcare system may also offer potential benefits in the management of certain infectious diseases.

unnormalised: In conclusion, infectious diseases continue to pose a significant threat to public health in India. Addressing this challenge requires a concerted effort from all stakeholders, encompassing improved sanitation, access to healthcare, public awareness campaigns, and research and development. By implementing evidence-based strategies and strengthening healthcare systems, India can make substantial progress towards reducing the burden of infectious diseases and improving the health and well-being of its population. Continuous monitoring and adaptation of strategies are vital, especially considering the evolving patterns of disease transmission and the emergence of new infectious agents. For instance, the unexpected surge in adenovirus infections in Kolkata during Dec'23 and Jan '24 highlights the need for a robust and responsive public health infrastructure.
